So what you're in real danger of doing is saying to men,
to the extent that you're more like a woman, you're less toxic.
And that's just not a great message to a 17-year-old boy.
Welcome to Politicalology.
I'm Ron Steslow.
In 1972, Congress passed landmark legislation to promote gender equality in
higher education.
Then it's Title IX.
At the time, there was a 13-point gap in the proportion of bachelor's degrees going to men
compared to women.
In 2019, the gender gap in bachelor's degrees was 15 points, even wider than in 1972.
But now, and it might surprise you to hear this, it's men who are being left behind.
In fact, over the last several years, there's been a growing concern about the struggles of
boys and men in primary education, college, and the workforce, the impact they have on our
politics and culture.
And we have to break free from zero-sum thinking if we're going to address the problems facing
boys and men and still work to solve the problems facing women and girls.
So today, we're going to dive into all of this with Richard Reeves,
who is the author of an excellent new book of boys and men,
why the modern male is struggling, why it matters, and what to do about it.
Richard is a senior fellow in economic studies and the John C. and Nancy D. Whitehead Chair
at the Brookings Institution.
He's the director of the Future of the Middle Class Initiative and the Co-Director of the
Center on Children and Families at Brookings.
He's a contributor to the Atlantic, National Affairs, Democracy Journal, The Wall Street Journal,
and The New York Times.
Richard is the former director of DMOs, the London-based political think tank, and holds a PhD from
the University of Warwick.
In addition to boys and men, his research focuses on inequality and social mobility.
Richard, it's a pleasure to welcome you to politicalology.
Great. Thank you so much for having me on, Ron.
Toxic masculinity, because you mentioned this a little bit earlier,
what do we need to understand about the term toxic masculinity?
What it means and why it's counterproductive?
It's a term that jumped out of the obscurity of certain academic journals in 2016.
Until that point, it was just used by academics who worked actually on incarcerated men with very
violent histories. It was a way in how had their ideas of masculinity, particularly growing up,
become entwined with ideas of violence and aggression.
It was just used a few times a year in journals that no one's ever heard of.
But then it broke out with the election of Donald Trump, me too, and that whole movement
into everyday language.
And then it then began its journey into becoming very unhelpful because it became essentially just
a way of saying bad stuff men do. It was very rarely defined.
So it intellectually became a pretty vacuous concept quite quickly.
And counterproductive, which most feminist scholars would agree now,
is unproductive, counterproductive because it pushes just men away from the conversation.
Being told that part of you's toxic or you have the potential of being toxic,
literally poison this, but we're just going to help you manage that or extract that.
It's just a bad start to the conversation.
It actually creates a bad conversation with boys and men.
And so it's actually turned out to be a very, very unhelpful term part because it's just used so
loosely for just pretty much anything boys and men do that the user of the term disagrees with.
Can we describe as toxic masculinity? So not wanting to wear a mask, not recycling,
whatever. It's all toxic masculinity. Using fossil fuels is toxic masculinity.
And does that become so general? But anybody, it's just it becomes close to a slur actually.
Right. And now I can see a proponent of the term saying,
hang on, wait a minute, we're not trying to say that masculinity is always toxic,
but the behaviors like suppressing emotions attempting to appear hard or using violence
and bullying as an indicator of power are bad. And you cite an article that Carol Harrington wrote
in 2020 about the term. And one thing that jumped out from that piece was that the term
toxic masculinity reinforced the idea that these are individual problems, not structural.
So can you talk about how that term,
toxic masculinity frames these behaviors as individual character flaws and not part of a
structural problem once again? Yeah, so it comes back to this, this individualization problem,
which is that the problems of men are very often framed as a problem with men. And so
there's a tendency to sort of describe any issues that men might be having through this individual
list of lens and toxic masculinity is a very powerful way of doing that. Right. And so for
example, the fact that men died of COVID in much bigger numbers than women among middle-aged men
the death rate was twice as high, at least 100,000 more men died than women in the US. And the initial
response to that, first of all, it took a long time to get attention to that fact. But even when
it does, there was a lot of discussion of how it's being caused by toxic masculinity,
because men drank too much or smoked too much or wouldn't wear a mask or whatever. And none of
that was true. It just actually is a biological vulnerability to the virus that men had. But it
was a really interesting and instructive example of the misuse of the term and this individualization,
right? If men are dying in high numbers, it must be because of something bad that they're doing.
And that then actually is very bad for policy because you think, well, actually, we should have
been thinking really hard about getting vaccines into the arms of men because they were dying in
such a fine sense. It's a really perverse form of victim blaming. Yeah, in that case, it's okay.
On the left, it's the only acceptable form of it than playing left, I think. It's hard to think
of many other areas where that's true. And so I think it can be very much bad for the formation
of policy. It leads you away from just an empirical approach to the problem. But then culturally,
it turns out to be a very unattractive phrase to the vast majority of boys in there. And so
it's just the framing. And so the advocate of that, they'd say, if they want to argue that there
are expressions of certain aspects of masculinity that are not good, maybe including someone's dimension,
sure, that's pretty hard to argue against just as there are for femininity. But to label them as
toxic means you're then in the business of figuring out which bits of you are toxic,
which things are your toxic and which are non-toxic. So the best you can hope for is to be not toxic.
Right. And that's just a horrible way to find it.
For boys and men, right? So don't be toxic. It reminds me, it reminds me a little bit
here of the idea of original sin. You know, that curious idea of original sin. It's a bit like
it's this thing that's in you. You know, it's been handed down. It's maybe, you know, and it's just,
just got to try and exercise it or deal with it. But there's a kind of brokenness implied by it.
It's only applied to men. And I know, so I think it's been an incredibly unhelpful term. And I think
the sooner people stop using it, the better, not least because the attempt to define non-toxic
masculinity in a way that is distinct from femininity almost always fails. It's just like,
it's an empty set. Non-toxic masculinity turns out to be femininity. And so that's
that you've just created a null set essentially. And so what you're in real danger of doing is
saying to men, to the extent that you're more like a woman, you're less toxic. And that's just not
a great message to a 17-year-old boy. Not a great message.
I love how you using data science terms to describe this problem and also.
But okay, so let's now turn to the politics here. So in the middle of the book,
toward the end of the book, part four, you talk about how some figures on the right
have made the argument that, air quotes, the left is conducting an all-out war on men
or that the left hates men. And this could be part of why it's so easy for people who are on
the left to dismiss the argument so quickly, right? Because it's quite a caricature of what's
real. And while that kind of hyperbolic claim is obviously intended, I think, to inflame,
the reality is that the left is in denial of the problem or they're blind to the problem.
And I think there's a difference there. There's a difference between ignorance or being unaware
and denial. And so I wonder if you could tease that out a little bit and tell us how you see
attitudes toward this problem on the left. And then maybe you can characterize the ideological
dynamics here and separate reality from rhetoric.
Yeah, so the difference between blindness and denial is an interesting one. And although I
talk about blindness, I think I'm reflecting on it, I'm probably referring to denial.
I think sometimes it's blindness. I mean, I am quite struck by how when I share even some of the
statistics that we've talked about, you've shared at the beginning, we're on and through this conversation
is how many people, even people in quite influential positions. They really? You sure? Yeah.
I'm like, yeah, I'm sure. I'm sure. This has been thoroughly fact-checked and peer-reviewed.
I'm totally on a broken senior fellow, sure. Please believe me.
Honestly, it's true. Like, it's true. Honestly, it's true. And like, really? Yes. That doesn't sound
right. It is right. But it's also classic sort of vicious circle because the less we're talking
about it, the less well-known this stuff is. And so it does come as a surprise. It does,
people do kind of question. So I think what's more likely to be happening for most of the folks
on the left who know about this stuff is that they do feel that accepting that there are real
problems facing a lot of boys and men now, publicly and addressing them actually will give fuel
to the people on the right who say that society's failing men, men are struggling,
men are the new victim, et cetera. And so they just don't talk about it at all.
It's just silence, like CDC is one example, but it's just true. The gender policy council at the
White House won't mention it. There's just like, there's no, it cannot be discussed.
I think that's a very bad political miscalculation because if it's true, that's
statement, I think suicide or struggling in education or whatever, you can't hide that truth.
Unless you're going to stop publishing data, it is going to be out there. And if you're not
talking about it and acknowledging it as a problem and setting up task forces and stuff to do about
it, it's very easy then for reactionary figures on the right to say, boys and men are struggling
true. They don't care about it. Kind of feels true if you're not volubally talking about it.
So it sounds very plausible. Josh Hawley is making a very, he says, Josh Hawley has his own book coming
out. It's called man. Oh boy, there's a much better style than mine.
A traditional book that he says exactly what you've just said, which he's a good case study of this,
which is boys and men are struggling true. The left take them, sounds plausible,
given how bad the left is mishandling this issue. So vote for me and I'll bring back
manufacturing and marriage with some magic wand that only Senator Hawley has.
Hold on a minute. And how are you going to do that Senator? But anyway, policy's not really
the point here. The point and then each side of course polarizes the other. The more that one side
emphasizes the problems of boys and men on the right, the more the left feel that they have to
ignore or understate them. The more left to understate or ignore them, the more the right
feel the need to elevate them. But the deeper point here is that
it's an axiom of political cultures that if there are real problems in that culture,
in that society and responsible people are not addressing them and being seen and heard
addressing them, they do become grievances. Agreevances can be expanded and exploited and amplified by
reactionary forces. So I think that the states here are quite high because that's what I think
is happening for lots of these issues for boys and men. Yeah, I'm jumping ahead here in my notes
because this is a really perfect segue to negative partisanship, which we talk a lot
about on the show. And just as a reminder to listeners, this is the idea of essentially the
era that we're in, which is that more and more people are forming their opinions based on opposition
to political parties and figures they don't like rather than the other way around. And that
incentivizes politicians and parties to take increasingly more polarized and extreme positions.
And so I think what you're getting at is that that's precisely what we see playing out here in
the debates about around boys and men and even in the willingness to acknowledge the data that you're
offering. That's exactly what's happening. And that's the fear is that you get this negative
partisanship ratchet effect, right? That you've just described so well. And I absolutely see it here
and it's it's important to read as I'm sort of desperately trying to sort of try and get into
this space now in the sort of boring Brookings chart led way that I am now is to try and deescalate
this, try and make this much more boring, much more earnest, more policy based, more charts,
fewer speeches, because I do see absolutely that happening. And I think when Josh Hawley
talks about the left-hating men and their aftermaths and anything and so on, and you see the left
responding by talking about women. And there's a war on women. And it seems like you can,
there's either war on men or war on women. And you just sort of decide which there is. And it sort
of feels unlike to both of those things happening at once. So it's really just this question of like,
which side you're on, right? And you choose, you basically choose your war. And then choose your
side. And if it's framed in that way, which really is being done on both sides, not allowing ourselves
think two thoughts at once and say, here are the ways in which women and girls feel obviously
struggling to need kind of help. And here are the ways that boys and men are struggling. But neither
side wants to do that, because it will mean them giving up on this kind of base motivating
rhetoric, which is, if you're on the right, the feminists are destroying masculinity,
they hate men, or on the left, the conservatives hate women, and they're stripping them, it's
sending us back to handmade tale. And don't even mention boys and men. And that cycle is really,
really turning at the moment. I want to go back. It was something else that really jumped out at me
in the book was the difference in resources and infrastructure between people and groups
institutions who are looking into the problems women and girls are facing as compared to boys
and men. My eyes popped out as I was reading this section of the book. So maybe you can explain to
people, when we talk about the differences in infrastructure and resources, what does that
landscape look like? Can you can you sort of describe how lopsided it is for someone who might
think that, Oh, there's just a lot of researchers looking into a lot of things and it's pretty well
distributed? Yeah, so it's absolutely not the case. And some of the conversation we've just been
having. But I mean, there is a, there is a huge institutional asymmetry when it comes to focusing
on issues of gender in one way or the other. So there are hundreds of thousands of organizations
and huge amounts of money public and philanthropic going into advocate research and advocacy on
behalf of women and girls. Much of that stems from, you know, some of these organizations
go back to the women's movement in the 70s, but a lot of them are much more recent. So you're
seeing a lot of states now creating women's commissions, Washington State, for example, created
women's commission in 2018. A lot of colleges and universities are creating women's commissions
on their campuses. And Melinda Gates is just spending spending a billion dollars on gender
equality in the US. And so you'll get societies like women and, you know, women and engineers
will take a pic of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, the National Organization of Women,
the we have a national coalition of women and girls in education. It's still does good work.
We have the American Association of University Women and so on. And there are no equivalents
on the other side. And you might argue that what we didn't need them before, and that might be true
that we didn't, but we do now. And it's a very important point. It's in no way to say that we
don't need the ongoing work on behalf of women and girls in many of those areas. It is to say
that absent any on the other side, I don't mean this side in a zero somewhere, just need any
organizations that creates this huge awareness gap. You just don't know the stuff. Because it's
nobody's responsible's job to be drawing attention to the problems of boys and men.
And so the only people who are drawing attention to them are typically those who are either
amateur's and there are some amateurs out there working out their basement trying to get the
stuff out and they're good, many of them. And then there's a bunch of angry people and there's a
bunch of stuff on the internet. And so there's this huge vacuum in the debate, which is self-fulfilling,
because when you go to policymakers, as I'm doing a lot of spending a lot of time trying to
persuade them that they should do more on this, that they say, well, what's the problem?
They don't know that there's a problem. But the reason there's a problem is because no one is
alerting them to the problem. And if you're a newspaper reporter, as I was for many years,
and you want to write about something, a new research report comes out, that's something to
write about. And so the best example I have of this, I think, is what happened during COVID,
which is that there was a huge number of reports and analyses on the impact of COVID on women's
girls, huge. Every institution, because there's a UN Council on Women and Girls, there's gender
policy getting. So there's just lots of people whose job it is to get up and say, how is this
pandemic going to affect our group by women and girls? And a lot of it was good. Most of the
fears, by the way, turned out to be unfounded. Thank God. Women's employment's bounced back a
bit more strongly than men. Domestic violence rates went down during the pandemic. The share
of women in senior management went up. So there's a lot of good news that came out, but I understand
the fear that led to those reports. The problem is no one was producing a report saying that the
college enrollment rates for men dropped seven times more than for women in 2020. Nobody was
producing reports saying, you know, men are dying at least 50% and in some cases, 100% higher rates.
No one was doing that because, like, name the institution whose job it is to do that. And the
answer is, it does not exist. That then creates this awareness advocacy policymaking thing. And
it creates this incredibly dangerous culture and political vacuum that then reactionaries of one
former another are really, really exploiting right now. But it's kind of our fault.
Going back to the zero sum game for a moment, especially with that as a backdrop and the blindness
and the negative partisanship, this book came out at the end of last year before this round of
fighting over the debt ceiling and congressional spending was upon us and we're likely going to see
now cuts to discretionary spending across the board at the federal level. How do you think that
could, you know, this new, this dynamic that we're in now over the budget,
could fuel these zero sum arguments? How would you counter them? What would you say to lawmakers
who are now going to be facing a pretty severe budget, budget problems when it comes to
discretionary spending, the discretion spending that fuels a lot of and funds a lot of the research
that we're talking about? How would you help them think about this? Yeah, well, that's why it does
get more difficult because obviously limited resources can fuel, you know, the sense of zero sum.
And I think again, when it comes to public resources, it's important to be honest here,
which is if, for example, the White House gender policy council were to spend more of its time,
or any of its time on issues on boys and men, then that's a certain amount of time and political
capital that would not be being spent on women and girls. I think I would have made that argument
on its merits and just say there are some issues where the gaps are so big the other way now that
you really just should, if your goal is really to get generated into a majority of the rest,
as much as anything else. And then I would make, yeah, I'd make, you got to decide what you're about.
And I think, and then I would make a kind of political argument too. But I would also say that
I think in some of these cases, just the mere fact of raising awareness and adding these
analyses to the sort of standard battery would be hugely helpful. So I'll just give you like
one example is that we don't know what the on time high school graduation rate is
of black boys in America, because the federal government doesn't require states to report sex
in their high school graduation rates. They have to report all kinds of other things. They don't
have to report sex. So I did some work on this. We have to go state by state to try and get the data.
The federal government requires states to report their on time high school graduation rates by rates
by English as a first language, by foster care status, by disability status and so on,
but not by sex. And so because of that, we can't do the intersectional analysis. We were
talking about earlier, like I don't know what it is for black boys because they don't collect
by sex. This is a classic and what gets measured, gets managed, right?
Yeah, and the reason I'm highlighting that is because that would cost the federal government
nothing to ask states to do that. It would cost states nothing to report it because they already
collected it, right? And so it's not like it was a new data collection for them. And then if
they reported it to the NCES, we would have the data nationally. And so I would then be able to
tell you what the on time high school graduation rate of black boys and black girls and what in
the US it's right. So that's there's a free policy idea, which I have not made any progress with so
far. So part of it is just data and awareness and doing relatively small stuff. And the only other
thing I'll say is that when there are places where we really do think that a focus on boys and
men would help us with other problems in our economy and our society, but it would be as well
to look at them. So for example, if we really do face shortages of teachers and nurses and so on,
that's a really good arc doing more of what I suggest, which is working very hard to get
more men into those professions. Because right now we're trying to solve labor shortages with
only half the population. And that's just crazy. And we wouldn't do it if it was the other way
around. We'd automatically be thinking, how can we get more women into these professions?
And so we should do the same for men. So I do think there will be more of some areas where
there'd be a clear policy upside. Yeah. Okay, I want to talk a little bit about solutions.
And you mentioned one that you admit is fairly controversial, which is this red shirting.
Can you first of all maybe describe what this solution is, where it might fit in a, you know,
in an array of solutions that people ought to be considering. And then, you know, I'd love to hear
about what kind of criticism you've received, both constructive and not, and how you've dealt
with that, and what you think the path forward is for this line of inquiry.
Yeah, so the, this evidence is pretty clear, but in education at least there are big gender
inequalities that now run in ways that disfavor boys and men. And we've mentioned some of the
deaths, the data on that. So assuming we think that's a problem, then we should try and do
something about it. And I was very struck by the fact that almost one in four boys in the USK-12
system have been diagnosed with a developmental disability, but 23%, almost one in four. And at
that point, back to the structural thing, you have to say, you have to ask yourself, really,
could it not be the system at that point? Is there a danger that we're misdiagnosing developmental
disabilities here? Because we're judging against the system. And I think that is what's happening
in a lot of those cases. And so in education, one of the proposals, as you mentioned, is to
redshirt the boys. And what that means is to start them in school later, so that they're a year older
throughout schooling. And the real benefits, I think, will come and adolescence, where their
brains are just so far behind the girls. And so you hit this, when you hit high school, which is when
middle and high school, you see these massive gender gaps open up. It's partly because the boys
are just, they're just behind the developmental... Yeah, that's what you're all sort of right.
Yeah, just... I don't like saying less mature, because people think that sounds
normative, right? You're sort of eye-rolling, you're so immature, but in terms of brain
maturity, it's just true. So let's start the boys' school year later. By the way, that's something
that kind of elite schools and upper-middle-class parents, they're doing it already. This is not
breaking news in elite circles. Absolutely not. No, there's one... I report on this for the
Atlantic piece I wrote for them. One of the private schools in Washington, D.C., very well known,
but I can't name them, because they kind of gave me their data. They shared their data with me on
the birthdays of their graduating seniors, and 30% of the boys were quotes too old for that year.
So at some point, they started late, etc. And in those elite circles, the line someone gave me
is like, everyone knows there are two entry dates, one for girls, one for boys. This is like an open
secret in kind of elite circles. And there's some pretty good evidence that it would help. At the
very least, I think it should draw attention to the fact that there's this developmental gap
between boys and girls, which is now showing up now that we are allowing girls to show what they
can do in school and college. They're just blown right past the boys because they are at an advantage.
We leveled the playing field, and it turned out the girls are better players, because of this
brain. So it started the boys a year at night. But also, and I would say just as importantly,
increase the share of male teachers, we've seen a big drop in the share of male teachers in our
classrooms down to 24% of K-12 teachers now are male down from 33% just a few decades ago.
Only one in 10 elementary school teachers, almost no primary, no early years teachers are male,
almost two between two and three percent. And that trend is just getting worse.
And again, it's just not a policy area where anyone is doing anything, even though I have yet
to find somebody of any political background to disagree with me that it's a bad thing that we
have fewer and fewer men in our classrooms. But getting someone to do anything about it,
different story. And we're just watching the line get further and further and
not doing anything about it. And it's going to get progressively harder to get more men into
teaching, because the more gender segregated any occupation becomes, the harder it is to persuade
people to go into it from the other gender. And then the last thing is more vocational training.
And I call for a doubling in the share of technical high schools, which is a very pro-male policy.
Technical high schools are really good for boys. They don't seem to have much effect.
For girls, negative or positive, they're much more popular with boys and the parents of boys,
and they have great outcomes from Connecticut and Massachusetts studies. And so I would love it
if every decent size city in the US had at least one technical high school that the boys could go to.
Because the last two grades of high school for a lot of our boys are really not great.
They're not years of rich human capital development. They're just like the boys are just limping
through them and then falling off the end. Yeah. Okay, before we go, I want to spend a little bit.
I didn't answer your thing about criticism. I wanted to come back to that, because I wonder,
and you can feel free to take this. Everyone loves it.
I mean, at first I was thinking, you know, what was going through your mind when you decided to
take on this project, given all of the headwinds that you knew there would be, and how have those
manifested in the, you know, in the reception, and how have you dealt with the criticism, whether
it's been fair, constructive, not so much, and what sort of, what is the experience been like?
Because one thing that I'm thinking about now, that I'm aware of the data and the problems,
after reading this fantastic book, is how to advocate more effectively without
incurring political wrath, right, for talking about these things as a problem.
I'd love to hear your thoughts on all of that, but the experience and then how to be a better
advocate for change. Yeah, so one of the reasons that I did decide to embark on it was because of
the number of people warning me against it. And to be clear, that's not because I'm a sucker for
punishment. I don't, I don't, I don't say, yes, this will upset a lot of people, I should
definitely do it. It was precisely because of some of what we alluded to earlier, which is that if
you don't have Brookings senior fellows writing, you know, very, you know, data heavy policy-oriented
books on this subject, then you basically just see to the ground the people who just come at it from
a purely ideological agenda. And so I felt like if people were warning me that I shouldn't do it,
because if I did it, I would become characterized, caricatured, labeled as quotes, one of them. I'd
stop frothing at the mouth all of a sudden and, you know, become incredibly angry and whatever.
I'd be one of them. Then I thought, I've got to do it then, right, because that's the very
definition of the self-fulfilling prophecy. If we create an environment, so hostile to even the
discussion of this, anybody who goes into this treacherous terrain, it's described as brave,
right? Then God, I've got to do it.
Precisely for that reason, because if I can't do it, then who can?
And I will say on the kind of, you know, people sometimes say, you know, you're brave to write this
book. And I actually saw sound very unforgivably masculine, but I'm going to say anyway, that I
actually have a picture of my great grandfather before in the Battle of the Song, and was sufficiently
wounded that he couldn't return to his job as a coal miner. And so I had to switch to other things.
I have a picture of him, tied best. He's from the Welsh side of my family.
And I just have that picture of him on my phone, and I have it more generally.
And I think, I think what I imagine a conversation with my great grandfather, perhaps just after he'd
survived the Battle of the Song, about, you know, how courageous I was being about writing this book,
and how courageous I was in during these nasty tweets that I get to the occasional email. And
I'd say, don't you think I'm brave? And I want to imagine how he would look at me.
And so I just think this whole courage thing is so massively overplayed. And it's such a kind of
self-balorizing thing. Like, yeah, come back to me when you actually done something. But in terms of the
